description: From Middle French prophane, from Latin profānus (“not religious, unclean”), from pro- (“before”) + fānum (“temple”).

adjectives.description: profane (comparative profaner or more profane, superlative profanest or most profane)

entries.meaning: Unclean; ritually impure; unholy, desecrating a holy place or thing.
Not sacred or holy, unconsecrated; relating to non-religious matters, secular.
Treating sacred things with contempt, disrespect, irreverence, or scorn; blasphemous, impious.
Irreverent in language; taking the name of God in vain
examples: a profane person, word, oath, or tongue

entries.meaning: A person or thing that is profane.
examples: The nuns were employed in religious duties established in honour of St Clare, and to which no profane was ever admitted.

verbs.description: profane (third-person singular simple present profanes, present participle profaning, simple past and past participle profaned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To violate (something sacred); to treat with abuse, irreverence, obloquy, or contempt; to desecrate
examples: One should not profane the name of God.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put to a wrong or unworthy use; to debase; to abuse; to defile.
